thig2.3:1.2: Both _musala_ and “pestle” derive from roots “to pound”. This verse is difficult, but I think hinges on double entendres of kitchen drudgery and sex.
thig2.3:1.3: Commentary explains that _ahiriko_ refers to the husband. BJ offers the variant, _ahitako me vāto vāti_; reading _vāti_ makes this line and the next syntactically parallel. According to [pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:10.21.7](), wind (_vāta_) is a cause of erections. _Chattakaṁ_ could be either “mushroom” (sprouting up) or an “umbrella” (being opened); I retain the kitchen imagery.
thig2.3:1.4: [pli-tv-bi-vb-pc5]() depicts a woman standing downwind (_adhovāte_) due to supposed vaginal odors.
